definition: To give up a position of power or responsibility, especially as a ruler.
examples: The king abdicated in favour of his son.
She refused to abdicate her duties.

extra.memory_tip: Abdicate = ‘abandon the dictate’—give up the throne.

definition: To take on a role or responsibility; to suppose something without proof.
examples: She will assume the role of captain next term.
Don't assume the results until we finish the test.

extra.memory_tip: Assume = either ‘take on’ or ‘take for granted’.

definition: To do something clumsily or badly; a clumsy or failed job.
examples: He bungled the easy pass. (verb)
The report was a complete bungle. (noun)

definition: To control or have a lot of influence over; to be the most noticeable or important.
examples: Their team dominated the match.
The tower dominates the skyline.

extra.memory_tip: Dominate = be ‘on top’ of the situation.

definition: Having come before in time; previous.
examples: She is a former champion.
The former owner left detailed notes.

definition: A person who protects or is legally responsible for someone or something.
examples: Her aunt is her legal guardian.
The dog acted as a loyal guardian.

definition: To stop or catch something or someone before they arrive.
examples: The defender intercepted the pass.
Customs intercepted the shipment at the border.

extra.memory_tip: Intercept = step in and stop the path.

definition: A special anniversary or celebration, often marking many years.
examples: The town held a jubilee for its 100th year.
They organised a silver jubilee celebration.

extra.memory_tip: Jubilee = joyful big birthday of an event.

examples: He visited his kin over the holidays.
Next of kin must sign the form.

definition: Official forgiveness for an offence; to forgive or excuse.
examples: The prisoner received a full pardon. (noun)
Please pardon my mistake. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Pardon = part done—let the rest go.

definition: To announce something publicly and proudly.
examples: The mayor proclaimed a holiday.
She proclaimed her innocence.

extra.memory_tip: Proclaim = proclaim it from the rooftops.

definition: To cause a reaction, especially anger or strong feeling.
examples: The remark provoked an argument.
Smoke can provoke a coughing fit.

definition: The period a ruler is in power; to rule as a monarch or be the most important.
examples: Her reign lasted fifty years. (noun)
Chaos reigned after the storm. (verb)

definition: A violent public disturbance; to take part in a violent public disturbance.
examples: Police broke up the riot. (noun)
Fans rioted after the decision. (verb)

definition: A way or course taken to get from one place to another; to send or direct along a particular path.
examples: We chose the scenic route along the coast. (noun)
Please route the parcels to the main office. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Route = the road you use; to route = to send by that road.
